entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
17/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirteenth edition:

Andy:
  • A Hacker’s Replacement for GMail - If you are willing to operate your own mailserver this is a good starting point.
  • The case against using RubyGems.org in production - A screed + a screencast showing you how to host your own gems.
  • Stickler - Stickler is a tool to organize and maintain your own gem repository.
Tony:
  • Demeter: It’s not just a good idea. It’s the law. - A very interesting demonstration and solutions by Avdi Grimm.
  • Swapping Rails Stack Traces for a REPL - You do like pry? Better Errors? THIS is the thing for you!
  • Adapter Registry - Store your decorators in a in-memory registry, and retrieve them in the correct context! (Shameless plug)
Floor:
  • Web Development Teaching Materials - A variety of CC-licensed web development curriculum which was developed for GirlDevelopIt SF. Useful to students as well. via @bastilian
  • The Open Source Report Card - Enter a GitHub username to see a dynamically generated progress report for their open source contributions. With graphs and charts and EVERYTHING!
  • [CSS Minion][13] - How cool is this: Minion drawn entirely using only HTML&CSS.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
9/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the twelfth edition:

Andy:
  • Foundations of Computer Science - Although the book has been taken out of print by W. H. Freeman, you are welcome to read it online. And I suggest you do.
  • The Elements of Style in Ruby #2 - Second in its series, topic being the following rule from the Ruby Style Guide: Favor the use of sprintf and its alias format over the fairly cryptic String#% method.
  • ALL teh bots - Do you know how to create a bot in Ruby? Now you do!
Tony:
  • Gems that need help with Rails 4 - A Gist started by Steve Klabnik
  • Bogus - a library that aims to reduce the risks associated with isolated unit testing.
  • Drain the oceans! - … and let the Netherlands rule?
Floor:
  • console.image - The one thing Chrome Dev Tools didn’t need. The day has come when you have the ability to put images in the console.
  • Programming Trends - Programming trends on StackOverflow.
  • Interview with Matz - The future of computing, the future of computer programmers - an interview with Yukihiro Matsumoto.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
2/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the eleventh edition:

Andy:
  • The Foreman - The Foreman is a complete lifecycle management tool for physical and virtual servers.
  • Packagers don’t know best - Why package maintainers and the authors of software should work together.
  • Packaging and the tide of history - And the follow up.
Tony:
  • ripper-tags - fast, accurate ctags generator for ruby source code using Ripper (work in progress - please check the upstream, too)
  • Chicken chicken chicken - chicken chicken
  • Report from EuRuKo 2013 - by Clemens from Codeship
Floor:
  • tosdr - Because “I have read and agree to the Terms” is the biggest lie on the web.
  • Huboard - Instant project management for GitHub repositories.
  • Inc - App to share knowledge within your company, from the makers of Kippt. Disclaimer: I’m a HUGE Kippt fan.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
26/6 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the tenth edition:

Andy:
  • Performance Optimization With Pry-debugger - A nice introduction to the Pry-debugger
  • The Boy Who Loved Math - The Improbable Life of Paul Erdös. A cute book for kids.
  • Where everyday is Caturday - Need a nice kitten as a placeholder? Or just a random kitten for your chatbot?
Tony: (with support from @fadr)
  • Rails 4.0 - Final version released!
  • Vertical Centering with CSS - Huge guide, nice explanation of the css methods used.
  • Responsive Patterns - Interesting approach for designs that change with media sizes.
Floor:
  • GitHub Similar Repositories - Great Google Chrome add-on, that helps you discover & upvote similar git repos on GitHub.
  • Teach Like You Don’t Know - A ‘serial beginner’ on how teachers can’t relate to their students because they know too much. Good read!
  • deploy via Git - Straight-forward walkthrough deploying via Git.

entry.title: Fifth meetup is Testing and Continuous Deployment themed
entry.content:
Codeship.io sponsors vienna.rb user group get-together

The vienna.rb organizing team can’t wait for their next developer get-together, taking place Thursday, July 18 at co-working space Sektor5 (Siebenbrunnengasse 44, Vienna).

The meetup is sponsored by Codeship. Manuel Weiss, cofounder of Codeship, on why they support vienna.rb:

We love what vienna.rb is doing and want to start giving back to the city and people who have given us so much.

Codeship

The vienna.rb team is collecting topics for lightning talks from their community. The topics so far - Making your tests faster; Continuous Deployment; Building and distributing virtualized development environments - make for an interesting evening of knowledge exchanging and networking. A little time is always reserved for spontaneous lightning talks from the attendees.

Vienna.rb meetups are open to both experienced Ruby developers and people that are new to programming.

For more information regarding the program and more upcoming events, please visit vienna.rb on meetup or follow @viennarb

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
19/6 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the ninth edition:

Andy:
  • A Short Story on Human Error - There is no single root cause or the further back you go in time, the more reasons you’ll find that there’s a tangled web of lots of little causes, that again have their own causes.
  • Your top 100 unix commands, for science! - Contribute your daily used Unix commands.
  • Rapid Web Development in the Browser using Espresso - Interesting and fast way to push out a prototype.
Floor:
  • svn-git - crash course to svn for (former) git users, written by yours truly.
  • version eye - Follow your libraries and get notified about new versions. Visually neat tool.
  • gist-dep - Anytime you want to re-use code but the amount of code is so small it would be silly to create a library.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
11/6 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the eighth edition:

Tony:
  • PostgreSQL 9.3: What’s new - Beta information about the Best RDBMS Ever™
  • Best Google+ Profile Ever - Support the T.S.A.!
  • For More Pair Programming - Get support for your project.
Floor:
  • git log - Bored and tired of the old git log screen? Try this.
  • geo-bootstrap - My new favorite CSS bootstrapper: it has comic sans, funky colors and MC Hammer.
  • Office Pi - GoCardless cooked up a fancy Office Dashboard Pi.

entry.title: The slides of our fourth meetup are online
entry.content:
Brace yourselves, the slides are coming

Hi there, we just pushed the slides of the fourth meetup to our repository. Feel free to check them out.

Markus Prinz - 10 things you didn’t know about Postgres
Martin Natano - Implementing git-orm
Gerald Bauer - Using Markdown for building books, websites or presentations

Like what you see? Join us for our next meetup, July 18 at Sektor5!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
4/6 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the seventh edition:

Andy:
  • How Go uses Go to build itself - I am always fascinated when a programming language can compile or interpret itself.
  • Afraid of the big nasty gem? - Ever thought about evil code in a RubyGem you use? Or how can I trust software of 3rd parties?
  • http://ascii.io/ - ascii.io is a neat tool to make command-line based screencasts, where you even can copy and paste the text.
Floor:
  • E.V.E. - E.V.E. is a Star Trek / Jarvis type computer written in Python. Run the program, and E.V.E. will activate whenever you say “okay computer,” after which you can ask it a question / command.
  • GitLab Summer of Code - GitLab (the open source alternative to GitHub) is a Google Summer of Code project.
  • PyLadies Vienna - As one of the co-organizers of PyLadies Vienna I can’t help but promote our beginners course to Python. Spread the word!
  • Raspberry Pi - Learn what other people use their Raspberry Pi for!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
29/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the sixth edition:

Andy:
  • Introduction to Randomness and Random Numbers - A good read on why it is so hard to get a computer generate good random data.
  • Storm SSH - A nifty tool that helps you organizing your SSH config.
  • Rails Girls summer of code - Support them as much as YOU can. It’s a great and important project.
Tony:
  • logstash - a tool for managing events and logs. In JRuby!
  • The Principles of OOD - Object Oriented Design. Uncle Bob Martin. ‘nuff said.
Floor:
  • content management with version control 1 - I wrote a little something to help group bloggers ‘version control’ their content with GitHub…
  • content management with version control 2 - … and then I wrote a follow-up post, processing the feedback I got on Twitter and the likes.
  • mephisto - Remember Mephisto, that blog engine based on Rails? It has been forked & revived by Sebastian Gräßl, so take a look!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
22/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fifth edition:

Andy:
  • Git Tools - Debugging with Git - Git helps finding the commit that broke your tests. Its like debugging on steroids
  • gti - The sl for git.
  • equatable - Allows ruby objects to implement equality comparison and inspection methods.
Tony:
  • Crafting Rails 4 Applications - Pragmatic Bookshelf beta: Expert Practices for Everyday Rails Development
  • Python 3 Metaprogramming (youtube) - David Beazley gives a 3 hour live tutorial - informative and funny!
  • explain.depesz.com - A tool for finding a real cause for slow queries. (for PostgreSQL, what else?)
Floor:
  • HTMLify - Turn your code into pluggable HTML.
  • LearnStreet - If you’d care to refresh your JavaScript knowledge or - like yours truly - want to take Python for a spin.
  • The Rails View - As discussed in Ruby Rogues episode 104: The Rails View. On my birthday wishlist.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
15/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fifth edition:

Tony:
  • git-scripts - My own scripts that I use with git flow. Currently has one to delete merged branches interactively or automatically. (Shameless self-plug :-P)
  • Something Completely Different - Neil Gaiman Addresses the University of the Arts Class of 2012 (Phl). If you are involved in any kind of creative processes, you should watch it.
  • Vimium - The hacker’s browser. Brings vim commands to Chromium/Chrome.
Floor:
  • Eurucamp CFP - Eurucamp’s call for papers ends today at midnight. Make sure to sumbit a proposal!
  • GitHub Training in Non-Traditional Schools - GitHub on how they support alternative models of training new programmers.
  • RailsConf 2013 Review - A nice recap of this years RailsConf (Portland) by Rizwan Reza.
  • Tabulous 2 - Adding tabs to your Rails app just got a whole lot easier
  • Hello, IT, have you tried turning it off and on again?] - The IT Crowd returns to Channel 4 for a final episode

entry.title: The slides of our third meetup are online
entry.content:
ALL the slides

Hi there, we just pushed the slides of the second meetup to our repository. Feel free to check them out.

Andreas Kopecky on Sequel
Sarah Howorka on the Rails Girls project and a bunch of other stuff
Clemens Helm on the Codeship workflow

Like what you see? Join us for our next meetup on June the 6th at Sektor5!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
08/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fourth edition:

Andy:
  • Testing Tuesday #4: Continuous Integration and Deployment with Cucumber - codeship.io has a great series testing and deployment you should follow.
  • Writing a good README - Why a good README is important and a few tricks that help you with it.
  • Birth and death of a running programm - A deeper look on the lifecycle of a C program.
Tony:
  • The Daily WTF - relax and laugh - or choke on the worst code you’ll ever see.
  • Relish - Living documentation (if you use cucumber). Including RSpec, cucumber, mongoid, diaspora et al.
  • Draper - Decorators for Rails Applications
Floor:
  • git eep - Fellow vienna.rb’er Tony wrote some great stuff about how to deal with git on his ‘blag’.
  • Vincent & Emily - Modern day love story.
  • Compuritas - This Austrian startup collects old hardware, repairs, reconditions it, and sells it to people who, otherwise, would not be able to afford it.

entry.title: Third meetup sponsored by Runtastic
entry.content:
Ruby on Rails user group meetup taking place at Sektor5

After a full house for both the first and the second vienna.rb meetups the organizing team can’t wait for their next developer get-together, taking place Thursday, May the 9th at co-working space Sektor5 (Siebenbrunnengasse 44, Vienna). Vienna.rb meetups are open to both experienced Ruby developers and people that are new to programming.

The meetup is sponsored by Runtastic:

At Runtastic we’re using Ruby and Rails since our foundation in 2010. We like to keep our developers happy, and thus bet on Ruby whenever we can. With many members of the Ruby community being present at the vienna.rb meetup, we might meet one of our future colleagues there.

Runtastic

The vienna.rb team collected topics for talks from their community. Starting with David Österreicher from Runtastic, Sarah Howorka will then talk about the Rails Girls project. Clemens Helm will eleborate on ‘The Ruby workflow’ and Andreas Kopecky will give us an insight on why he uses Sequel and its advantages to Active Record. A little time is always reserved for spontaneous lightning talks from the attendees.

For more information regarding the program and more upcoming events, please visit vienna.rb on meetup or follow @viennarb

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
01/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the third edition:

Andy:
  • The Most Difficult Bug - How to solve the most difficult bug of them all.
  • Building a Ruby Library - ‘Building a Ruby Library, the part no one talks about’, great talk by Mitchell Hashimoto, at Aloha Ruby Conf.
  • color theme - An Emacs color theme based on Heroku.
Tony:
  • Clean Coders - Code Casts for Software Professionals. Check out the first vid in the clean code series for a sneak peek. Not for free, but full of value.
  • Method Finder - a smalltalk like method finder for ruby. A real smart piece of software, and useful for beginners and professionals.
  • Her - an ORM (Object Relational Mapper) that maps REST resources to Ruby objects. Much more configurable and easier to use than ActiveResource.
Floor:
  • bieber.ly - The best url shortener EVER. Thank you, Elliott Kember.
  • gizoogle - Fo’ all y’all biotches who wanna find shiznit!
  • Railsberry revisited - What happened at Railsberry centainly did not stay at Railsberry. I tried to write a few recaps, you’ll find them on my Tumblr.

entry.title: MySugr
entry.content:
MySugr switched from Ruby to Java. Here’s why:

Vienna’s most beloved startup must be mySugr, creating an app to help people fight the ‘diabetes monster’. mySugr was founded by Frank Westermann, Fredrik Debong, Gerald Stangl and Michael Forisch in 2011 and launched in April 2012. Today they are a team of 20 and they’ve welcomed over 10.000 people from Austria, Germany and Italy, using their application.

I talked with Bernhard Schandl, Technical Director and Gerald Stangl, Creative Director, about mySugr’s switch from Ruby on Rails to Java.

Here’s to the big question: why did you switch from Ruby to Java?

Gerald: We started with Ruby on Rails, as the team I did consulting work with consisted of Ruby guys. We however hired a new technical lead who was very proficient using JVM based systems and had loads of people in his network who had a track record using Java. All the local Ruby developers I knew were talented but didn’t have that much professional experience. It was too risky to build an application in RoR, if those guys would have left the company for whatever reason, we would have had a technology nobody else could really work with. It was really hard for me to let Rails go, though.

Bernhard: When I came in 3/4 months ago, the whole Java setup was already in place. mySugr already had loads of users and it was out of the question to change the code base again. I’m experienced with Java, I never build full webbased projects in Ruby, or wrote production code in Ruby for that matter. Ruby is great for a lot of things, I mean, you sit down and after an hour you have a running webapp. For quick iterations Ruby is also great. Software gets more complex overtime with every project, no matter which programming language you use, we just opted for the more mature language.

Gerald: We’re dealing with highly sensitive data, mySugr is a medical device. The Java libraries we use are reliable, bullet-proof technologies, used and developed by a lot of companies before us.

Bernhard: We have regulatory restrictions enforcing us to really investigate a third party library before using it.

Gerald: We operate in a regulated environment and we’re a young company, we didn’t want to make mistakes, so we chose the most secure way. It was not so much a technical decision, we just want to protect our users. Plus: we had to consider that with mySugr we’re dealing with iOS, Android and the backend. Drilling down our languages to Java and Objective-C made sense as we wanted to keep the team small. There simply aren’t many Ruby guys in Vienna that are proficient in Objective-C as well…

How many developers are working on mySugr?

Bernhard: The dev team is 5 people, some work part-time, and they are for the bigger part based in Vienna. Our remote workers check in every several weeks, stay for a few days and we always try to get a beer then. We have a daily standup that takes about 15 minutes and a weekly Show & Tell, limited to 1 hour. We use a JIRA ticketingsystem and Basecamp, although that’s more for the conceptual part of the design & development process. And we use Campfire to quickly post updates. I’m always here (at Sektor5) to try to answer all the questions concerning database excerpts and such, so the developers are not disturbed.

What’s new in mySugr’s next release?

Gerald: The new mySugr is brighter, we have a new monster and some new challenges. It offers multi device syncing and your location is now - more than ever - important. The user experience evolves around pictures (images of food and drinks you take) and push notifications remind you to finish your challenges or document your lunch.

Bernhard: Our junior app was just released last week, also on Android. You should check that out too!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
24/4 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the second edition:

Andy:
  • git-code-review - An extension to git to help you with doing regular code reviews of other team members’ commits.
  • Essentials of Garbage Collection - This is a very nice approach on understanding how GC works and what it does.
  • If you are busy you do it wrong - A bit older, but shows you why ‘elite performers’ perform the way they do. It’s not only the genius that matters.
Tony:
  • git-wtf - a script to display the state of your repository in a readable and easy-to-scan format.
  • Benchmarking in Ruby - a short overview and nice examples.
  • Sequel - The Database Toolkit for Ruby (especially if you use PostgreSQL)
Floor:
  • tmux Quick Start - Just what I needed: a brief introduction to what tmux can do and how it works.
  • Glitché - Ridiculous, but oh so awesome: Glitché (iPhone app) Distort your photos using computer errors and bugs
  • Karaoke - There’s a KaraokeParty at the Metalab this Friday. You don’t want to miss that for the world. Believe me.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week

In a little series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s to the first edition:

Andy:
  • CodeTriage - Help your favorite open source projects. They have bugs, they need help!
  • Why does it call the “wrong” equal method? - on Stack Overflow - The title is pretty much selfexplainatory.
  • Return to the Essence of Text Editing - Emacs is a pretty neat everything, but also a decent text editor.
Tony:
  • Objects On Rails - a “developer’s notebook” documenting some guidelines, techniques, and ideas for applying classic object-oriented thought to Ruby on Rails applications.
  • Clean Coders - educational videos for software professionals, by software professionals.
  • vim-rails - vim is the best rails editor of all times.
Floor:
  • Bootstrap HTML Button generator - Bootstrapping buttons. Because why would you want to reinvent the wheel?
  • List of Hello World Programs in 300 Programming Languages - A complete list of “Hello World!” programs written in more than 300 existing programming languages including Assembly language, Low-level, High-level, Object Oriented, Document formats, Page description languages and Scripting languages. How awesome is that?
  • starlogs.net - Putting Geek in GitHub. Once more.

entry.title: The slides of our second meetup are online
entry.content:
ALL the slides

Hi there, we just pushed the slides of the second meetup to our repository. Feel free to check them out.

Floor Drees, introducing the Coders without Borders project
Gerald Bauer on his beer.db and world.db gem
Tomáš Kramár on ‘open’ data in Slovakia
Anton Bangratz opened up his big o’ bag of tricks

Like what you see? Join us for our next meetup on May the 9th at Sektor5!
